awd_titl_txt: Thermo-compositional convection in the interior of giant planets
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, Dr. Garaud and her collaborators will expand their modeling to include analysis of transport layered convection, with the goal of solving long-standing problems, such as understanding why Saturn radiates more energy than predicted by models, and why Uranus and Neptune give off much less than expected.  They will also test whether incorporating helium gradients can improve the thermal evolution models of Saturn and Jupiter. 

This project has broader impacts in that it will train students in interdisciplinary scientific research, and produce results that are applicable in fields outside of astronomy, including applied mathematics and global oceanic mixing.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The research funded by this award looked into a fundamental process called "convection", which drives turbulence and ultimately causes the transport of heat and chemical species in giants planets, stars, and many objects in the universe (including the Earth's atmosphere and oceans, as well).

Convection requires a sufficiently large temperature difference between the center of the planet/star and its surface to proceed, and can be inhibited by a "bottom heavy" distribution of chemical elements. We have studied a peculiar kind of convection called "thermocompositional convection" that occurs when this chemical inhibition is particularly strong, which often takes place near the cores of giant planets, as well as in special layers within the planet where chemical species become segregated (i.e. the He rain region). 

We used numerical experiments on supercomputers to study this process, and were able to quantify the rate of transport of heat and chemical species caused by thermocompositional convection as a function of various inputs, such as the local temperature and chemical profile within the planet, as well as microscopic properties of the fluid such as its viscosity and diffusivities. We have found that this kind of convection has a natural tendency to become layered, i.e. to spontaneously form stacks of thicker turbulent regions separated by relatively thin, significantly less turbulent ones. These layers migrate and merge regularly, so the turbulent layers thicken over time. The rate of heat and chemical transport increases with the layer thickness, in a manner that we modeled empirically. 

Our models for the heat and compositional transport in this form of convection were then used to improve planetary evolution models, which were then compared with actual data from both Jupiter and Saturn. In all cases investigated, we have found that our numerical experiments put into question the commonly accepted paradigms for planetary structure and evolution, and now suggest that further work should be done to include additional physics, such as the effects of rotation, latent heat release and absorption, and the settling of Helium drops. 

Giant planets in our solar system being generally rapid rotators, we studied the effect of rotation first. Using numerical experiments, we have found that rotation can affect thermocompositional convection, if it is strong enough. Interestingly, we discovered that it can cause the appearance of very peculiar vortices that are robust, and that can channel and enhance the transport of heat and composition. The consequences of our findings for our solar system planets remain to be more generally investigated.
